articles.headline: In Andrew Yang, the Internet Finds a Meme-Worthy Candidate
articles.snippet: Mr. Yang’s presidential campaign has catapulted out of obscurity thanks in part to a devoted online following, including some fans he’d rather not have.
articles.abstract: Mr. Yang’s presidential campaign has catapulted out of obscurity thanks in part to a devoted online following, including some fans he’d rather not have.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you visit the online betting market PredictIt, you’ll see a long list of 2020 Democratic candidates, ranked in order of their odds of winning the party’s nomination for president, according to the site’s users.

articles.headline: Giant Military Contract Has a Hitch: A Little-Known Entrepreneur
articles.snippet: Deap Ubhi has spent his tech career bouncing around. Now he’s tangled up in a little battle over one of the biggest government I.T. contracts in history.
articles.abstract: Deap Ubhi has spent his tech career bouncing around. Now he’s tangled up in a little battle over one of the biggest government I.T. contracts in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deap Ubhi is a restless guy. At 26, he quit his job in private equity in Northern California, where he had grown up and gone to college, and then moved to India to found Burrp!, a local search site similar to Yelp. He sold the company in 2009 and along with other alums became what they called the Burrp! mafia, seeding and growing other start-ups in India.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Months After John McCain’s Death, Trump Keeps Feud With Him Alive
articles.snippet: The president said he gave the Arizona senator “the funeral he wanted, and I didn’t get ‘thank you,’” escalating attacks on Mr. McCain that began over the weekend.
articles.abstract: The president said he gave the Arizona senator “the funeral he wanted, and I didn’t get ‘thank you,’” escalating attacks on Mr. McCain that began over the weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Ohio — It is an obsession he cannot seem to shake.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Michael Tackett

articles.headline: How Companies Learned to Stop Fearing Trump’s Twitter Wrath
articles.snippet: Two years into President Trump’s term, many businesses appear to be increasingly prioritizing their balance sheets over political backlash caused by his efforts to compel them to build and hire.
articles.abstract: Two years into President Trump’s term, many businesses appear to be increasingly prioritizing their balance sheets over political backlash caused by his efforts to compel them to build and hire.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, some of America’s largest corporations were tearing up their business plans to accommodate President Trump, fearful that he could send their shareholders and customers fleeing with a tweet. Now they have a new strategy: Ignore him.

articles.headline: Days After Cyclone Idai, Rescuers Battle to Save Victims
articles.snippet: Nearly a week after southern Africa was hit by one the worst natural disasters in decades, it was all rescue workers could do to try to reach the flooding victims.
articles.abstract: Nearly a week after southern Africa was hit by one the worst natural disasters in decades, it was all rescue workers could do to try to reach the flooding victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAPUTO, Mozambique — The fierce winds and torrential rains slammed into three of the poorest countries on earth, upending the lives of more than one million people in a matter of minutes.

articles.headline: New Zealand to Ban Military-Style Semiautomatic Guns, Jacinda Ardern Says
articles.snippet: The announcement on Thursday from New Zealand’s prime minister came less than a week after a massacre at two mosques in Christchurch.
articles.abstract: The announcement on Thursday from New Zealand’s prime minister came less than a week after a massacre at two mosques in Christchurch.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand on Thursday announced a national ban on all military-style semiautomatic weapons, all high-capacity ammunition magazines and all parts that allow weapons to be modified into the kinds of guns used to kill 50 people at two mosques in Christchurch last week.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Charlotte Graham-McLay

articles.headline: I Deleted Facebook Last Year. Here’s What Changed (and What Didn’t).
articles.snippet: Our personal tech columnist didn’t lose touch with his true friends — but strange things did occur, including Instagram thinking he was a woman.
articles.abstract: Our personal tech columnist didn’t lose touch with his true friends — but strange things did occur, including Instagram thinking he was a woman.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Facebook and its family of apps experienced a daylong malfunction last week, millions of people got a taste of what life would be like if the social network were out of their lives for good.

articles.headline: Doomed Boeing Jets Lacked 2 Safety Features That Company Sold Only as Extras
articles.snippet: Airlines had to pay more for two optional upgrades that could warn pilots about sensor malfunctions. Boeing now plans to make one of the features standard.
articles.abstract: Airlines had to pay more for two optional upgrades that could warn pilots about sensor malfunctions. Boeing now plans to make one of the features standard.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the pilots of the doomed Boeing jets in Ethiopia and Indonesia fought to control their planes, they lacked two notable safety features in their cockpits.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and David Gelles
